Award.AwardTitle: Closing the STEM Divide: Opening Access to STEM Careers.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at the Community College of Aurora in Aurora, Colorado will provide scholarships to students enrolled full-time in STEM disciplines. Twelve scholarships will be offered at the beginning of each academic year to begin a new cohort of STEM scholars. The program includes comprehensive support and transition services, with a particular emphasis on cohort development and support. These activities will increase STEM course success, program retention, and graduation and four-year transition rates. Program graduates will contribute to the continued success of the aerospace, software, and other technology-based industries in the region. Scholarships for academically strong students, who may not otherwise be able to afford college, will increase the number of graduates prepared to support national, regional, and local companies. The success of the program will produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the economic growth of Colorado and the nation.

Through this S-STEM program the Community College of Aurora (CCA) will conduct a five-year effort to recruit, support, and graduate students with academic talent and demonstrated financial need. The program will provide twelve scholarships in years one and five of the program, and twenty-four in years two, three, and four. A new cohort of STEM scholars will begin at the start of each academic year. Scholarships will renew for a second year provided scholars meet academic targets and other program requirements. CCA will encourage applications from first generation, women and students from groups currently underrepresented in STEM professions. Improved retention and increased graduation rates will be achieved through comprehensive support and transition services, with a particular emphasis on CCA-based STEM faculty and cohort support. Mentoring will include regular meetings with an assigned STEM faculty mentor. Learning community activities organized around cohorts will focus on study and tutoring needs, guest lectures on STEM careers, visits to STEM companies and four-year academic programs, and other career development activities. Lessons learned and effective practices that emerge from the program evaluation will be disseminated to the STEM education community and help increase widespread understanding of the attributes and practices of successful student scholarship and support programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Community College of Aurora’s (CCA) NSF S-STEM project entitled Closing the STEM Divide: Opening Access to STEM Careers for Underrepresented Students (award No. 1458447 for $570,000; award period:  9/1/15–8/31/20; PI: Martha Jackson-Carter, co-PI: Keith Howard) enrolled 5 cohorts comprised of 95 unique students, providing scholarships and associated faculty mentoring and cohort-based student support services. The average scholarship amount across the current cohorts was $4,700 per year. Results from project were very strong with 80% of participants meeting project outcome goals of persistence, graduation and/or transfer to a four-year institution. In comparison, only 51% of all other STEM students at CCA completed their degree, transferred or remained at CCA after three years over a comparative time period (CCA IR Office, December 2018). Among S-STEM scholarship recipients, STEM course (biology, chemistry, computer science, engineering, environmental science, geology, math, physics) success rates (grade of A, B or C) across the S-STEM cohorts averaged 95.5%. The overall grade point average for scholarship recipients in STEM courses across cohorts averaged over 3.36, easily meeting transfer requirements to area four-year STEM degree programs.  Of the 95 students served over 5 years: 67 (71%) graduated or transferred, 4 (4%) are continuing at CCA, 1 (1%) joined the workforce, 1 (1%) transferred to another community college, 3 (3%) were unsure of their plans after CCA, and 19 (20%) dropped out of the program.  Demographic data for the 95 students served include: 7.4% Asian, 32.6% African-American, 2.1% Native American/Pacific Islander, 30.5% Caucasian, 27.4% Hispanic/Latinx. 

CCA served 34% more S-STEM scholars than originally projected—95 as compared to the original goal of 70 scholars across the five-year project. CCA was able to increase the number of scholarship recipients through strategic leveraging of financial aid and other scholarship resources and due to students’ faster rate of transfer to four-year degree programs resulting in less need for continuing scholarships than originally expected. CCA S-STEM scholarship recipients are transferring to rigorous, competitive STEM programs at the University of Colorado Boulder, University of Colorado Denver, Colorado School of Mines, Colorado State University, Regis University, and Metropolitan State University to continue working toward a STEM bachelor degree.

CCA’s S-STEM scholarship program is helping to advance the stated goal of the S-STEM program: to increase the number of low-income, academically talented students with demonstrated financial need obtaining STEM degrees. CCA’s program served low-income college students: 63% were low-income based on Pell eligibility and all demonstrated financial need based on the FAFSA calculation of unmet need after Pell grants and other federal aid options. 

This project contributed broader impacts as evidenced by the institutional changes and lessons learned at CCA that may be informative for other institutions. Specifically, the Closing the STEM Divide project compelled CCA to advance its STEM initiatives beyond the passion and commitment of one science faculty member leading a single project to a college-wide, multi-department effort. Using the ECC Trilogy model as the framework, CCA’s STEM departments established a common vision and goals for increasing STEM student engagement, capacity and continuity, including classroom interventions, co-curricular engagement —such as the launch of a new Innovation Lab with interactive engineering design workshops, 3D printers and other hands-on learning opportunities—and a more structured approach to student support using a STEM Coordinator. CCA’s embrace of the Guided Pathways approach (Bailey, Jaggars, Jenkins, 2015) during this same time period resulted in streamlined and enhanced advising for STEM students to put them on a more structured and focused academic path. With this shift came dedicated STEM Pathways Advisors now incorporated into the STEM student support structure. Further, the majority of project participants were students of color, 55% were underrepresented minorities, and 69% of the participants served to date were first-generation college students, contributing to the eventual full participation of these groups in STEM.
